title: Zubin Damania's Evolution from Burnout to Revolutionizing Healthcare
content: In this episode, Zubin Damania, a.k.a. Zdogg MD, a Stanford trained physician and founder of Turntable Health, discusses his evolution from disillusioned doctor suffering burnout to leading the charge for a radical shift in how we practice medicine.

title: The Impact of Stress on Physical and Emotional Health
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: Factors Contributing to Chronic Illness
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., provides insight into the factors that contribute to chronic illness.

title: The Impact of Stress on Chronic Illness, Dementia, Depression, and More
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: Physiology of a Stress Response
content: Robert Sapolsky explains the physiology of a stress response and why it’s ingrained in our DNA.

title: Individual Variation in the Response to Stress
content: Robert Sapolsky talks about individual variation in the response to stress and how everyone has a different optimal level.

title: The Impact of Stress on Memory and Health
content: Robert Sapolsky discusses the role of stress on memory and the consequences of hypercortisolemia, as well as the impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health.

title: The Impact of Stress on Cancer, Atherosclerosis, Dementia, Addiction, and Depression
content: Robert Sapolsky explains the impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression.

title: Physician Burnout and a Broken System
content: Zubin and Peter discuss the hierarchies in healthcare and how they can lead to physician burnout and a broken system. Zubin believes that hierarchies can either dominate those underneath or treat them as equals inappropriately, leading to a lack of competence. Peter enjoyed hierarchy when he respected the person he was reporting to, but would steamroll those he didn't think were good enough, smart enough, or knowledgeable enough.

title: Moral injury in medicine
content: Zubin thinks that physicians are not 'burning out' but are suffering from moral injury. Moral injury can be summed up as follows: You were in a position where all the system was arrayed to make it very difficult for you to do the right thing for the patient. You knew it was the right thing. You knew the patient needed to have this done and you knew that it would cause serious consequences to you to have it done. Then you had to live with the shame and the guilt of NOT having done something that was self-destructive, that was not in your best interest, to help this other person.

title: Zubin's disillusionment with medicine
content: Zubin started to get disillusioned in general with medicine, because most of what they did seemed like bullshit. Most of what they did either harmed people or it just wasn’t thought out. It’s half baked. That causes a kind of moral distress.

title: Feeling burnout
content: EHR was implemented and the focus became revenue generation. He began taking his work home with him. Tipping point is when they had their first daughter “my burnout is expressing in how I’m treating my daughter.”

title: Meeting with Tony Hsieh
content: Zubin was making some videos and putting them on YouTube. It got the attention of Tony Hsieh the CEO of Zappos. Tony asked Zubin if he was happy, “Absolutely not. To see you living this life where you’re doing what you love and you’re financially successful and you’re affecting people’s lives.” After this discussion with Tony, Zubin felt depressed, would cry in the shower. Tony later asked Zubin what he wanted to do? “I did this speech for graduation. I felt so connected to the audience. I felt like I was revealing truth through humor that could help motivate people to change stuff. I would do that for a living.”

title: ZdoggMD was born
content: Created ZdoggMD so Stanford wouldn’t figure out it was him. Did these videos while working at the hospital full time for 2 years. First video: Colon Wars, a parody of talking about GI through the lens of Luke Skywalker going down the trench. Next came Manhood in the Mirror, which was the first big music parody of a testicular self-exam.

title: Going all in
content: Tony Hsieh made Zubin a proposition, “Come to Vegas and do something that’s going to transform medicine that’s about you and about the community.” Zubin thought the idea was crazy, but wanted to do it. So he quit his job, moved to Vegas, and started Turntable Health.

title: Peter’s tough decision to leave medicine
content: Peter left residency with 2 years left. But he was miserable and wife said, “fix the things that are making you miserable or leave”. So in 2005, Peter decided to leave medicine. Where to go? He wasn’t sure: “I didn’t know if I should go into another specialty, leave medicine altogether, go into the lab full-time. I had just come back from NIH where I had spent two years in the lab. All of these options were spinning through my mind.” He ended up taking a job as a credit-risk modeler for McKinsey & Company.

title: Benefits and challenges of meditation
content: Zubin found meditation very challenging until he read The Mind Illuminated. Zubin recommends The Mind Illuminated for nerds and type A's who want a process. Zubin has used Waking Up with Sam Harris and Headspace. Our mind is like a boardroom where you're projecting stuff on a screen, and that's our conscious awareness. These sub-minds are what's doing the projecting. We have an audio sub-mind, a visual sub-mind, and a narrating sub-mind that ties them together.

title: What got Zubin curious to start exploring mindfulness and meditation?
content: Zubin got curious about mindfulness and meditation after moving to Vegas in 2012. He had a transformative experience with marijuana and a Bikram yoga instructor. He realized that the awareness in which all this arises and moment to moment is the real him. That experience, combined with living in the desert of Vegas, and being told to basically reinvent yourself or go out of business was a personal awakening for him.

title: Challenges of learning awareness and mindfulness meditation
content: Peter found The Mind Illuminated very difficult to understand. He had an easier time understanding Waking Up by Sam Harris but admits that he still doesn't understand about ⅓ of the book. Peter recognizes that he is still in the infancy of his practice. He uses swimming as an analogy. He learned to swim as an adult and was frustrated watching other swimmers doing it with such ease compared to him. He tries to remember this lesson when he finds himself getting a little frustrated trying to understand consciousness.

title: A helpful metaphor that Zdogg continually comes back to throughout the episode
content: From psychologist, Jon Haidt, he coined the elephant and rider metaphor to describe the two different parts of the brain. The elephant is our limbic system, emotions, and unconscious.

title: Zdogg's theory of consciousness
content: Zdogg’s theory of consciousness is influenced by the work of Dr. Donald Hoffman. Synthesis of Zdogg’s theory of consciousness: Are we seeing a world as it is? Or a fabrication not even close to reality? Organisms that see any aspect of reality as it is, go extinct in just a few generations because it requires energy to actually see reality in all its complexity. Organisms that see reality as a fitness icon designed to help them reproduce will thrive. As humans, we have evolved a shorthand hack in how we see the world to help us survive… i.e. I see something wet that I know that if I drink it I will not die. So is there a reality? Yes, there is an objective reality, but our visual cortex is simply constructing the world second-to-second in our minds every day. Based on what? In quantum mechanics, it’s pretty clearly established that there is no such thing as local realism…in other words, something doesn’t exist until it’s interacting with a conscious observer. What is it that we are interfacing with? (Dr. Hoffman answers this question in his TED Talk)

title: Synesthesia and Evolution
content: People that experience the world very differently such as they smell colors, or they hear sights, or see colors when they hear sounds…parts of the brain that light up with touch, light up when they’re simply thinking about something specific. I would argue that the cortex is an icon we used to actually, consciousness interacting with itself…now imagine if evolution put pressures on us where the people with these interface mutations are at an advantage? It becomes the default. But to me, that is totally explainable through Darwinian Biology. That works just as well with conscious agents as it does with material stuff. Conscious agents can evolve over time to have perceptions that actually allow them to succeed in this social network where they’re competing.

title: Peter's Nutritional Strategy
content: Peter squirms at the question: “I don’t know how to put a label on it”. “I can define my objective, I can define the strategy, and I can define the tactics but other than that I can’t actually take an existing description and apply it to it”. Peter has a great talk about objective/strategy/tactics ⇒ Reverse engineered approach to human longevity. Objective: ⇒ Live longer than I am otherwise on a trajectory to live, which means I have to delay the onset of the things that will kill me. Cognition=Delaying neurodegenerative disease. The maintenance of muscle mass, the ability to move and maintain mobility and stability, freedom from pain, sexual function, the ability to be happy, having the highest degree of “distress tolerance” possible. Mindfulness and meditation becomes the single most important tool to impact that. Also important is social support and sense of purpose. For most people, if you took those things away from them, they wouldn’t want to live one more minute. Challenges of this approach: The Efficacy Problem: Figuring out the optimal way for an individual to eat, the good news being there is a finite number of iterations you can make until you start to converge on it. The Effectiveness Problem: By far the more challenging problem, which is finding a nutrition problem that actually works for the person, logistically or practically. Peter is a perfect example of the effectiveness problem, he knows he does best on a ketogenic diet but he simply doesn’t want to eat keto anymore, so this strategy is no longer “effective” for him. Peter’s nutritional framework: There is a spectrum. One end is the SAD, The Standard American Diet. The other end is complete caloric restriction (water only, obviously not sustainable, this should be cycled). In between those two ends of the spectrum, Peter says there are 3 other steps. It’s one thing to figure out how to optimize a person based on how they cycle between those layers, but the harder part is figuring out how to make that the default, as opposed to something you have to work into. How do we make it our default? Peter says he’s Influenced by Nudge by Dick Thaler. The easier you can make something for someone, the easier it’s going to be to do.

title: The anti-vaccine dispute
content: Zdogg interviewed Paul Offit on this topic. Story of how Peter lost a patient over vaccines. Zubin posits, “What you triggered was that person’s elephant. Their unconscious was triggered in a way where their entire conception of the world, their ideas of liberty versus justice, versus care, versus harm, this moral pallet that Jon Haidt talks about, which we can talk about more later. This idea that vaccines are a violation of the sanctity of the body so you’re putting toxins in the body. The idea that he probably went to you thinking you were a little bit off the grid, that you’re looking at the unique person and therefore you’re not going to swallow the dogma, right? But the truth is what he didn’t realize is no, you swallow what works. The things that have been shown to work are, in fact, vaccines.”

title: The reality of anti-vaccine literature
content: There was a single paper which made this an issue. But this paper has since been retracted because the calculations were wrong…it was fraud.

title: The common thread of all “diets”, the obesity epidemic, and Peter’s dream experiment
content: People treat nutrition like a religion. All “diets” are better than the SAD. Any diet you compare it to the SAD is amazing. People are solely focused: dietary restriction (keto, paleo, Mediterranean, vegan, vegetarian, etc.) to the exclusion of other interventions, such as: Time-restricted feeding, Hypocaloric feeding, Caloric restriction. All of these guys are trying to nuke each other, saying, ‘My diet’s the best.’ ‘No my diet’s the best.’. . .But what they’re forgetting is they’re all comparing it to SAD…All of your diets are better than SAD.'

title: Zdogg’s evolving personal nutritional strategy
content: N/A

title: Solving the obesity epidemic
content: Zubin believes it will take a multi-pronged approach and fat shaming. Peter believes that changing the environment is the key to solving the problem.

title: Peter's dream experiment
content: Peter's dream experiment involves taking two geographical areas and changing the food environment for one group while leaving the other group as a control. The experiment would run for one year in parallel and then cross them over.

title: Turntable Health
content: At Turntable Health, Zubin gave people the tools, education, guidance, and coaching to help them make better decisions and be held accountable.

title: Free will
content: Peter used to believe in free will, but now he's starting to understand the counter-argument. Zubin believes that thoughts and decisions bubble up from unconscious processes that we don't understand, and lack of free will doesn't mean there are no consequences.

title: Morbidity and Mortality conferences: A beneficial component of med school education
content: Peter really enjoyed M&M at believe it to be very beneficial in the learning process. Everybody would meet in a room and all of the complications, so the morbidities and then all of the deaths, the mortalities would be presented. Then comes the process ⇒ The audience begins questioning your process and decisions leading up to the death. Peter then went to work for McKinsey and wondered why they didn’t do M&M? The reason M&M works: It’s completely closed off to others not part of the system, and there is no legal recourse. Zubin had the same experience with pain, but so much benefit, of going through M&M. ⇒ “In the hospital, nurses often get fired if they make mistakes, and the truth is it ought to be a no-blame culture.”

title: Understanding life extension
content: Peter’s current obsessions: fasting and rapamycin, measuring autophagy, and becoming a kickass 100-year-old [2:03:15]. Obsession #1: Understanding what is the appropriate dose, and frequency, of caloric restriction, and of the molecules that mimic that. Molecules that mimic caloric restriction include: Metformin and Rapamycin. Fasting: Nothing but water, seems to work really well provided you do it in short enough periods of time. ⇒ The problem: We don’t have a clue what the optimal dose is. If you think about fasting as a drug: How long should you fast for (dose)? How often should you fast (frequency)? Furthermore, do you need to go all the way? Could you just eat 500 calories a day for a certain period of time? You pretty quickly realize that it becomes an infinite problem. Obsession 1-B: Understanding the readout states that would indicate life extension. If caloric restriction and/or rapamycin, and/or metformin extend life, what would be some of the readouts states of that? Peter is now obsessed with understanding those readout states. Assays need to be created to measure the readout states for autophagy ⇒ generally regarded as probably the most important, though not the only mechanistic change, that occurs under caloric restriction and administration of rapamycin. “I have spent years experimenting on myself with this stuff, but the measurement tools that I have are too blunt to actually make any reasonable inference.” Need a better study. Need better tools to measure what we care about. Is Peter using metformin or rapamycin on patients? Yes to metformin.

title: Rapamycin and Disease
content: Rapamycin given at certain doses at certain frequencies actually enhances the immune system, and improves many metrics of physiology. Rapamycin is safer than other drugs that are commonly prescribed such as Fluoroquinolones (a common antibiotic) which can cause tendon injuries and bowel infections.

title: Zdogg's Rant on Hospitals and Medical System
content: Hospitals are a disastrous zone of chaos, of infection, of errors, of poor system design, of lack of coordination and of expense that doesn’t need to be done. Our medical system is broken and needs reform.

title: Why Rapamycin is Exciting
content: Rapamycin not only increases lifespan, but it reduces the rate of healthspan decline. It has the potential to keep people out of the hospital.

title: Peter's Current Obsessions
content: Peter is currently obsessed with developing finer tools to probe the molecular places to be able to see readout states on caloric restriction, rapamycin, metformin, and other agents that are CR mimetics, meaning drugs that mimic caloric restriction. He is also interested in codifying what does the perfect training routine look like to make us be kickass 100-year-old.

title: Reforming the Healthcare Payment Model
content: Decision makers must bear the cost. Fundamentally if you want to fix the cost issue, you must be able to couple decision making to spend. Peter believes that a single payer system is the solution.

title: Disconnect between financial burden and decision makers in healthcare
content: Patients need more skin in the game. Under the current pricing regime, that would be impossible. So the answer isn’t patients need to spend more, they just need to own a greater share of the cost. Zubin’s solution: Give everyone a personal health account up to about $2500. It has to be used within healthcare (so there’s no incentive to not spend it). Use it for primary care. Preventative healthcare is incentivized. Flat membership fee for an unlimited, all you can treat access to a relationship-driven, preventative-mind, a team-based healthcare. You can look at the unique patient, you’re not subject to metrics beyond the patient having outcomes that matter to them. It’s people competing with each other based on what they’re providing to the patient. When the $2,500 is used up…⇒ Then it gets into deductible space. Wealthier people may have a higher deductible ($7500 or so) Low-income people: “It might be subsidized by either your employer or by the government to some degree, but your skin is still somewhat in the game, and so you’re paying for that.”⇒ Once you reach the deductible…Catastrophic Medicare kicks in. That is Medicare for all but not in a single-payer sense…it doesn’t pay for everything. It’s given out and administered in the same way that Medicare advantage is… in other words, different entities compete to be the most efficient with that money “You have businesses competing, you have the government covering everybody. Nobody falls through the cracks. Hospitals compete, doctors compete. But everybody gets to practice the way they want.”

title: Prevention primary care
content: At the center of it is prevention primary care  ⇒ That also ameliorates burnout for doctors. Then focus on science and technology that actually improves quality.

title: Medicalizing social problems
content: In this country we medicalize our social problems. Diabetes to a large extent is a social problem. It’s poverty, it’s lack of job security, it’s inability to exercise because of danger in the community, these kinds of things. It’s adverse childhood experiences. As a result, if you start shunting money from healthcare into those social services, like every other industrialized country does, you can actually squeeze down the overall cost. Yes, but the government must be the one who does that. I think that’s the role for government. People will disagree, the hardcore libertarians will disagree. Well, here’s the funny thing, I consider myself libertarian, which is such a broad term that it doesn’t mean much. . .but I actually found Michael Lewis’s book, The Fifth Risk to be quite interesting. . .I think Lewis does a great job explaining things that the government are good at.

title: Peter's Doctor Database
content: Peter is creating a doctor database through his website to facilitate patient-doctor introductions. Doctors can apply to be part of the database by answering a lot of questions about their process of re-education, philosophy on medicine, and more. The goal is to streamline the process for patients to find good doctors in their area.

title: Zdogg's Video Production Process
content: Zdogg's video production process starts with identifying a problem or message that needs to be communicated. Then, he finds the right song with the right emotional valence and lyrical structure. He reviews the original lyrics and structure and picks a title. Finally, he creates the track music with the help of an audio engineer friend.

title: Lyrics Writing
content: Peter Attia's creative process for writing lyrics involves listening to the original song, coming up with notes, and hitting certain points. He also uses exercise to help clear his mind and allow ideas to surface. He finds that having a structure in the song helps him excel and uses RhymeZone to hone his lyrics. The rewriting process is crucial and can take up to a month. The recording process takes a couple of days with 30+ takes, and Peter takes voice lessons to reduce the number of takes needed.

title: Cinematography
content: The music video is usually shot in a single day, with one take in a hospital and real practitioners as extras. Peter Attia is currently working on a parody of Barenaked Ladies' One Week called One Sikh, which is a tribute to foreign medical graduates from India and South Asia.
